December 11, 1914.

Mr. S, S. Kwan 
79 Montgomery Street

Boston, Mass.

My dear Kwan:

Thank you for your nice letter, and especially for letting me

dom so easily on my wpardonable carelessness in connection with that latter

I am indeed glad that you were not embarrassed by my

from ár. Whitnore. 
blunder.

Congratulations on the marks you have raceived thus far.

I know

something of the Technology marking system, and from that knowledge I am well 
aware that your record to date is a nighty good one. Keep it it and you will

carry away from the best institution of its kind in this country, if not in

the world, a record of which you and your friends will always be immen saly

proud.

By all means coine up sometime and talk over the question of your 
future occupation. This is one of the most interesting and important subjects 
a fellow like you has to consider, and it is one which should be given the most 
careful thought before the final decision is rade. I may not be able to

help you distinctly, but I would welcome gladly the chence to discuss the

question with you, and perhaps thereby contribute some suggestions that may

prove of value, I shall probably be here most of the Christmas recess, though 
it would be well to let md know in advance when you are likely to make the trip, 
so that you will not drop in on us to find me away.

Yes, Bartlet Hall went up in smoke a couple of nights ago. At least 
the two top floors were thoroughly burned out. The fire probably started in the 
vicinity of the chimey, though we don't know just how or where. Nobody was 
injured, and we hope to have the building restored before the year is over.

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter apologizing for the blunder related to the letter from Mr. Whitmore. He congratulates Kwan on his grades and states that if he continues to do well, he will be very proud to have completed his studies at the best institution in the country. He welcomes Kwan's invitation to speak with him about his future occupation. He comments on the condition of Bartlet Hall after the fire.
